title: Hedera
content:
Hi people!

Hedera. Umm... what is it exactly? Ivy leaf... a horticultural dingbat... This little fellow ( [see veer's t-shirt](http://web.archive.org/)) has caught my attention a few times - always sitting by itself for no apparent reason. Is it just pretty? Or is there more to it than that?

Or am I just being haunted by the thing?
author: higashi

comments.content:
The Hedera was one of the first punctuation marks of Greek and Romans (beside Interpuncts). In the Middle Ages this meaning was forgotten and it became a decoration for title pages and so on. In Germany we also call it Aldus-Blatt, because the famous italien printer Aldus Manutius used it very frequently.

Ralf

[http://www.fonts.info](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042647/http:/www.fonts.info/ "http://www.fonts.info")

Thanks Ralf, a great answer. I can rest a little easier now. Judging by the web pages I have found, it would seem that the Hedera/Aldus-Blatt has been given more recognition in Germany than in other countries ( [example](http://web.archive.org/))... is that the case?

I feel a little guilty that the meaning passed me by, although I am sure I am not alone...

In the <cite>Character Palette</cite> (Apple OS X 10.4) I have found the hedera listed under <cite>Ornamental Punctuation</cite> as a <cite>floral heart</cite> and a <cite>rotated floral heart bullet</cite>. Both in Zapf Dingbats. Now I am forced to ask three more questions:

1/ Is it commonly known in Europe as a hedera, but more commonly referred to as a floral heart in the States? (I am British).

2/ Other than Dingbats, which character sets include the hedera?

3/ Was the original use always as a bullet?

Please forgive my ignorance!

<cite>it would seem that the Hedera/Aldus-Blatt has been given more recognition in Germany than in other countries </cite>

Yes, because Germany's most famous publisher of design and typography books ("Hermann Schmidt Verlag") uses it as their brand mark.  
But I don't think the ancient roots and the name Hedera are well known in Germany or elsewhere.

You can find some more information in Parkes "Pause and Effect – an introduction to the history of puntuaction in the west" and in Paul Saenger's "Space between Words".

I don't know which other typefaces include a Hedera. But if you find out more, please let me know. I would like to compare the different designs.

Ralf

[http://www.fonts.info](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042647/http:/www.fonts.info/ "http://www.fonts.info")

[Hedera](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042647/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Hedera) n. Latin, meaning ivy. One of the earliest typographic [ornaments](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042647/http:/typophile.com/wiki/ornaments), present in many Greek inscriptions.

Linotype [ornaments](http://web.archive.org/). So… a needless or much needed flourish?

Ralf: [Minion Ornaments](http://web.archive.org/) has quite a selection of Hedera.
